metadata.titleEn: Cathodoluminescence images (CL images) data set of detrital zircons from sandstone of Late Carboniferous-Late Permian strata in the Southern Qiangtang terrane and Early Cretaceous Hauterivian-Albian strata in the Bangong‐Nujiang suture zone, Tibetan Plateau.
metadata.description: This data set includes cathodoluminescence images (CL images) of detrital zircons from sandstone of Late Carboniferous-Late Permian strata in the Southern Qiangtang terrane and Early Cretaceous Hauterivian-Albian strata in the Bangong‐Nujiang suture zone, Tibetan Plateau. The sampling and shooting time is 2018-2019. The sampling areas of Late Carboniferous-Late Permian strata are Jiaco and Ritu areas of the Southern Qiangtang terrane. The sampling areas of Early Cretaceous Hauterivian-Albian strata are Baerqiao, Mabujiaco, Duochang and Kama areas of the Bangong‐Nujiang suture zone. CL images were taken in the Continental Dynamics Laboratory, Chinese Academy of Geological Sciences, Beijing, China These data provide a key limit for understanding the closing of the Bangong‐Nujiang suture zone. The opening time of Bangong‐Nujiang Ocean is limited to 300-279Ma, and the closing time is limited to 110-100 Ma, which is of great significance to explore the tectonic evolution of Tethys Ocean. The related articles of the data set have been published in the well-known journals《Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology》,《Tectonics》,《Geoscience Frontiers》, and the data results are true and reliable.
metadata.instructions: The cathodoluminescence images (CL image) are stored in tif format, and the file name is "CL2019B19T36.tif", where CL represents the content, 2019 represents the year, and B19T36 represents the serial number.

authorList.unitEn: College of Earth Sciences, Jilin University

literatureList.titleEn: From arc-continent collision to ocean closure: Lower Cretaceous Shamuluo Formation in the western segment of the Bangong–Nujiang suture zone, central Tibet.

Geoscience Frontiers, 12, 101207. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.gsf.2021.101207.

literatureList.titleEn: Timing of the Meso-Tethys Ocean opening: evidence from Permian sedimentary provenance change in the southern Qiangtang Terrane, Tibetan.

Timing of the Meso-Tethys Ocean opening: evidence from Permian sedimentary provenance change in the southern Qiangtang Terrane, Tibetan. Palaeogeography,Palaeoclimatology,Palaeoecology, 567.https://doi.org/10.1016/j.palaeo.2021.110265.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of cathodoluminescence images used to study detrital zircons in geological formations?

Quantification.Question: How many regions were sampled for the collection of sandstone zircon cathodoluminescence images on the Tibetan Plateau?

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes for understanding tectonic evolution processes when utilizing cathodoluminescence (CL) imaging of detrital zircons from stratigraphic layers, considering the time frames and regions specified?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The outcomes include providing key constraints on the opening and closing times of the Bangong-Nujiang suture zone, specifically narrowing the opening to 300-279 Ma and the closing to 110-100 Ma, which is significant for understanding the tectonic evolution of the Tethyan Ocean.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of collecting cathodoluminescence images of detrital zircons from sandstones in the Late Carboniferous-Late Permian and Early Cretaceous formations in the Tibet Plateau region?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to provide critical constraints on the opening and closing of the Bangong Lake-Nujiang suture zone, which is significant for understanding the tectonic evolution of the Tethys Ocean. The data collection aims to determine the opening time of the Bangong Lake-Nujiang Ocean between 300-279 Ma and the closing time between 110-100 Ma.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in capturing cathodoluminescence (CL) images of detrital zircon from sandstone strata in the Late Carboniferous to Late Permian and Early Cretaceous formations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The cathodoluminescence (CL) images of detrital zircon from sandstone strata were captured in the Late Carboniferous to Late Permian formations within the South Qiangtang terrane, and in the Early Cretaceous Hauterivian-Albian formations within the Bangong Lake-Nujiang suture zone. The sampling regions in the South Qiangtang terrane include Jiaco and Ritu, while the Bangong Lake-Nujiang suture zone includes Baerqiong, Mabujiaco, Duochang, and Kama. The CL images were taken at the Continental Dynamics Laboratory of the Chinese Academy of Geological Sciences (Beijing) during 2018-2019. These CL images provide critical constraints on the opening and closing of the Bangong Lake-Nujiang suture zone, with the opening time constrained to 300-279 Ma and the closing time to 110-100 Ma, which is significant for understanding the tectonic evolution of the Tethys Ocean.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the acquisition of cathodoluminescence images of detrital zircon in sandstone from the Late Carboniferous to Late Permian strata in the South Qiangtang terrane?
Enablement.Answer: The acquisition of cathodoluminescence images of detrital zircon in sandstone from the Late Carboniferous to Late Permian strata in the South Qiangtang terrane was enabled by the use of specialized imaging equipment within the Continental Dynamics Laboratory at the Institute of Geology, Chinese Academy of Geological Sciences in Beijing, during 2018-2019.
